2.
Inhalation of Benzypyrene and Cancer in Man
by
E. Cuyler Hammond, Sc.D.*
Irving J. Selikoff, M.D.**
Patrick J. Lawther, M.D.***
Both cigarette smoke and polluted urban air contain very small amounts
of benzo(a)pyrene, or BaP, a substance which is carcinogenic to experimental
animals if relatively large amounts are applied in certain ways such as skin
painting or subcutaneous injection. This suggested the possibility that the BaP
in cigarette smoke might account for the high degree of association between
cigarette smoking and lung cancer; and it suggested the possibility that BaP
pollution of urban air might perhaps increase the risk of lung cancer.
Wynder and Hoffman found an average of 2.5 micrograms of BaP in the
smoke from lo0 American cigarettes smoked mechanically. Based upon this, it
would appear that even during; a lifetime of heavy cigarette smoking, the con-
centration of BaP per square centimeter of bronchial tissue over which it might
be spread would be extremely small as compared with the dose required to produce
skin cancer in mice.
The concentration of BaP in the air of large American cities is
reported to vary from about 0.3 to 6.0 micrograms per I,ooo cubic meters in
summer and from 6.0 to as high as 74.0 in winter. The air of British cities is
in winter
more heavily contaminated with BaP. In some British cities/it varies from 73.0
. to as high as I7o.0 micrograms per I,ooo cubic meters of air. During the course
of a year, non-smokers living in some of these cities probably inhale far more

DISCLOSURE
The presont invention is a Continuation-In-Part-of Serial
No.-696,699, filed January 10, 1968, -entitled "Gmoke-Pilters".
The present invention relates generally to smoking producte
and more specifically to synthetic materiale suitable af tobacge
subatitutes,
It is well known that tobacce snoking, while a widespread
practice, may tend to have undesirable effects-on the smoker's
health. These effecta are believed' to be attributable to the
presence_in the tobacco smoke of various components, which-if
inspired in-significant amounts over a peried of time may-yield
harmful effecta. -For a considerabie number of years, attempta
20:-, have been made to reduce amounts-of these_componente in tobacce
smoke.' -Recent emphasis by governmental agencies has reaulted
in increased activity in-this area.
-Essentially, two-approaches have been taken in attempting
to find a solution to thia problem. Firet, attempts have been
cade to remove certain-components by filtration of the smoke
through a material such as paper or cellulose acetate filamenta.
To date, the most significant gains in overcoming the aforesaid
problen have been achieved by this technique.

AN OVERVIEW OF THE VAPOR PHASE, SEMIVOLATILE
. AND NONVOLATILE
E COMPONENTS OF CIGARETTE SMOKE
Vello Norman
Research Department
Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company
Durham, North Carolina
27702
Introduction
Four previous major reviews on the composition of cigarette
smoke have been published by Johnstone and Plimmer in l959 (30),
Stedman in 1968 (67), on the vapor phase of smoke by Elmenhorst
and Schultz in 1968 (1.2) and on nitrogenous smoke components by
Neurath in 1969 (46). The 1967 book by Wynder and Hoffmann (76)
also reviews the composition of smoke, principally from the
biological point of view.
After the appearance of each of these reviews more and more
sophisticated analytical chemical technology has been developed
and applied to smoke analysis and hence the number of compounds
reported has increased tremendously. At the same time, the quan-
titative aspects of smoking methodology have been quite widely
recognized by the workers in the field and virtually all of the
tit
more recent publications adhere rather closely to the accepted
standard conditions of cigarette preparation and smoking-
Another event of great significance to those who aspire to
make quantitative comparisons was the emergence of the Kentucky
Q000027365
lRl Reference cigarette in l969. The lRl is widely accepted as
a standard cigarette and very commendably, many authors, whenever
they have worked at developing procedures for the determination

of these agents have been termed negative in other in vitro and in viv

ulness of the: L5178Y/Tk+/- bioassay at PM.
V79: CHINESE HAMSTER CELL MUTATION ASSAY3
An excellent dose response was obtained using these cells treated wit
and hamster liver S9 as the source of activation. As expected, no
ponse was observed in the absence of S9. [In the previous experiment,
tle or no dose-response was seen with hamster s9 because too high a dose
tested.] A. second experiment was completed: this month using DmBA and
rat liver S9 as the source of activation. [Rat liver S9 is the activat
tem of choice used in other in vitro assays at PM.] The results from th
eriment revealed that, as expected, DMBA was. active only in the presence
rat liver S9. An almost linear, four point dose response was observed.
 most important finding was that at least for this chemical the shape an
gnitude of the dose response curve was. almost identical regardless of the
rce of the microsomal activation (rat or hamster liver S9). This. sugges
it rat liver S9 can be used in future experiments where metabolic activat
required.
